awd_titl_txt: NRI: Receding Horizon Integrity-A New Navigation Safety Methodology for Co-Robotic Passenger Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to ensure the integrity of vehicle position, heading, and velocity estimates that are used by self-driving cars as the basis for life-critical decisions such as the initiation and execution of hazard-avoidance maneuvers.  Integrity, which is a measure of trust in a sensor's information, has been successfully implemented in commercial aircraft to guarantee the safety of maneuvers such as landing. This project addresses several obstacles in translating integrity from aviation applications to self-driving cars, including integrating the disparate sensor types used by ground vehicles; meeting the stringent demands of routine autonomous driving; accounting for the number, proximity, and high relative velocity of other vehicles on the road; and evaluating multiple, distinct, and mutually exclusive courses of action in a timely manner. Project subtasks include characterization of integrity for representative sensors, construction of appropriate models for uncertainty propagation, and experimental validation of the resulting integrity framework. The project will advance the larger research effort to realize the potential of self-driving cars for relieving congestion, reducing emissions, and saving lives. The work includes public outreach efforts on autonomous navigation for self-driving cars, which will build upon an ongoing relationship with Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry, including a hands-on demonstration during National Robotics Week to illustrate how safety can be ensured despite uncertainties related to sensor readings, vehicle dynamics, and the driving environment.

Specifically, this research will provide new experimental and analytical methods to quantify and prove self-driving car safety. The results of this work will create a high-level, sensor-independent, quantifiable metric that can be used to compare, evaluate, and certify safety across self-driving car manufacturers. Knowledge will be advanced in several previously-unexplored areas, including first-ever demonstrations of: 1) high-integrity sensor measurement error and fault models for non-GPS sensors, 2) analytical methods to quantify the safety risk of feature extraction and data association algorithms required in lidar, radar, and camera-based localization, 3) multi-sensor pose estimators and integrity monitors designed to evaluate the impact of undetected sensor faults on safety risk, and 4) rigorously derived and experimentally validated integrity risk prediction methods in dynamic environments.

por.por_cntn:
This research developed an analytical framework to quantify localization safety for mobile robots while accounting for the impact of undetected sensor faults.  The research has applicability to autonomous passenger vehicles and represents a critical step in proving that autonomous passenger vehicles and other co-robots that operate in life-critical situations are safe. 

All mobile robots need to localize - that is, identify their position and heading angle in relationship to the surrounding environment.  Most mobile robots localize by using sensor information such as GPS signals, lidars that identify the distance to nearby objects coupled with feature extraction and data association algorithms, inertial measurement units, wheel odometers, radars, and cameras. The problem is that these sensors are both noisy and potentially faulted. This means that localization is not deterministic, but rather probabilistic.  In other words, a robot cannot identify its exact position and heading, but rather the robot assigns a probability to a particular position and heading. 

In terms of intellectual merit, mobile robot localization has historically only accounted for the fact that the sensors are noisy. The results are perfectly adequate for small numbers of robots operating in non-life-critical situations.  However, with the upcoming adoption of self-driving cars, the need to analytically guarantee mobile robot safety while accounting for the impact of undetected sensor faults is imperative. This research was the first to do so for lidars, a critical localization sensor for most autonomous vehicles. 

In terms of broader impact, the technology that we developed can help prevent car accidents that cause over 30,000 deaths/year, cost approximately $230 billion/year in medical and work loss costs, and are caused by humans 90% of the time. By 2040, mass adoption of autonomous vehicles is expected. This will be a paradigm shift in transportation that will incur numerous benefits if and only if a vehicle's safety can be guaranteed. These benefits are predicated on consumers adopting the technology, of which safety is undoubtedly an important factor.

The analytical safety guarantees that we have developed could serve as the foundation upon which government regulating agencies and manufacturers can quantifiably prove a mobile robot's localization safety. This will ensure that the probability of an accident due to navigation errors is low enough to not erode confidence and delay adoption by the public.

Current techniques to prove autonomous vehicle safety, such as those employed by most of industry, use a brute force, experimental-only approach where the best outcome is that a vehicle is "safe" because it has driven a set number of miles without an accident. This is problematic because the approach would require billions of driven miles to just match current manned vehicle accident rates. This is three orders of magnitude larger than any current effort. Furthermore, during that testing period any navigation errors, sensor changes, or algorithm modifications would necessitate the experiment to restart. Last, experiments would need to represent all US roads under all weather conditions.

In contrast, our methodology: 1) identifies when sensor information is not reliable enough to continue with the current operation; 2) creates quantifiable, sensor-independent metrics to assess mobile robot navigation safety across manufacturers; 3) provides a governmental regulating agency performance and testing standards for certification; and 4) ultimately reduces the time to large-scale autonomous vehicle adoption.
